channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: 3 Americans Killed in ISIS Attack in Syria, Trump Says, Vowing to Retaliate
item.description: Two soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed while supporting counterterror operations, the Pentagon said. They are the first U.S. casualties in Syria since the fall of the dictator Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Christina Goldbaum, John Ismay and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American Bradley fighting vehicles during a joint exercise in 2021 with Syrian Democratic Forces in northeastern Syria.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Senior Hamas Commander, Despite Cease-Fire
item.description: Hamas said the attack on Saturday was a breach of the truce. The militant group did not comment on Israel’s claim to have killed one of its members.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed car following an Israeli strike in Gaza City on Saturday.

item.title: Belarus Frees Prominent Political Prisoners as U.S. Lifts Some Trade Sanctions
item.description: The release of the prisoners, including a Nobel laureate and two opposition leaders, was part of a monthslong rapprochement between Washington and Minsk.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Tomas Dapkus
item.media:description: Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, a Belarusian opposition leader, welcoming Ales Bialiatski, a political activist released by Belarus, as he arrived Saturday at the U.S. Embassy in Vilnius, Lithuania.

item.title: Russia Bombs Ukraine Port of Odesa Amid Peace Talks
item.description: Much of Ukraine’s largest Black Sea port was without power, heat and water on Saturday after strikes from Russia, which has shown little appetite for a deal to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:description: Firefighters on Saturday at the site of a Russian strike in Odesa, Ukraine.

item.title: Chile Poised for Right-Wing Victory as Crime Fears Sweep Latin America
item.description: Security has become a top concern for voters across the region who are calling for iron-fisted measures. In Chile, the issue is pushing the country to the right.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Sara Wayra
item.media:credit: Sara Wayra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chilean police raiding a house in Iquique during an anti-gang operation last month.

item.title: Ivan Urgant Was Russia’s Late-Night King Until Putin’s War in Ukraine
item.description: Ivan Urgant was an unstoppable Russian megastar. Then he expressed opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: The Russian entertainer Ivan Urgant, right, hosting “Evening Urgant,” which went dark in 2022, after he made an antiwar post on social media.

item.title: Can Trump’s Grand Plans for Gaza Get Off the Drawing Board?
item.description: The next steps for the president’s 20-point Gaza peace plan have been mired in uncertainty and a lack of detail, but that may be set to change. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Natan Odenheimer and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians sheltering last month in tents surrounded by destroyed buildings near Gaza City.

item.title: North Korean Soldiers Return From Russia’s War With Ukraine
item.description: Kim Jong-un hugged the returning troops and awarded the country’s highest medal to nine soldiers killed in action.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, hugs a soldier in Pyongyang during a ceremony welcoming troops home from a deployment in Russia’s Kursk region, in a photograph released by state media.

item.title: Korea’s English Exam Was So Hard It Prompted an Apology. How Would You Do?
item.description: South Korea has a notoriously grueling college entrance exam. This year’s English portion was so difficult that it led to a resignation. Could you answer some of the questions correctly?
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Students waiting for the start of the annual college entrance exam, known as the Suneung, at an exam hall in Seoul in November.

item.title: Thailand Rejects Trump’s Claim That It Reached a Cease-Fire With Cambodia
item.description: The conflict appeared to have continued unabated on Saturday morning, a day after President Trump said a cease-fire was supposed to have resumed.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Sun Narin
item.media:description: A damaged bridge in Cambodia’s Pursat Province on Saturday.

item.title: Ukrainians, Worrying More About Power Cuts, See U.S. Peace Push as Just Noise
item.description: Many understand the dance their leaders must perform to appease President Trump. But that doesn’t make them any less weary of the rounds and rounds of talks.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Laetitia Vançon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: For 2 Hours, a Soccer Match Offers Palestinians a Rarity: Joy
item.description: The national soccer team made it to the knockout stages of the Arab Cup for the first time, uniting fans from Gaza to the West Bank to Cairo to Arab cities in Israel.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger, Bilal Shbair and Fatima AbdulKarim
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times

item.title: With Dreadlocks and Yoga, Oslo’s Bishop Practices an Atypical Evangelism
item.description: Sunniva Gylver, the new Lutheran bishop of Norway’s largest diocese, is having success attracting younger worshipers while preaching an ancient message centered on justice.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since becoming the Bishop of Oslo in the Church of Norway, Sunniva Gylver, second from left, has focused on making the church as inclusive as possible.

item.title: In Rome, the King of Paparazzi Is a Star in His Own Right
item.description: Rino Barillari has been snapping photos of, and sparring with, the famous for 65 years, from Princess Margaret to Lady Gaga, Peter O’Toole to Spike Lee. He is now a fixture himself in the celebrity firmament.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rino Barillari, at Harry’s Bar, in Rome.

item.title: AfD Pushes to Publish German Information That Officials Say May Help Russia
item.description: Opponents of AfD lawmakers say that their push to publish sensitive details about national security could benefit Russian military planning.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The leaders of the AfD, Tino Chrupalla, front left, and Alice Weidel, front center, have defended the party against accusations of compromising national security.

item.title: Six U.N. Peacekeepers Killed in Drone Strike in Sudanese Battle Zone
item.description: The strike on a United Nations base in the southern Kordofan region was the deadliest single episode for the body’s personnel in Sudan’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Sudanese rallied on Saturday in support of government forces in their battle against the rival Rapid Support Forces, in Omdurman, outside Khartoum, the capital.

item.title: Baby Steps
item.description: The antidote to our increasingly disembodied lives may lie in letting go of our inhibitions and dancing like kids do.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Reporting on Arctic Sovereignty in the Polar Bear Capital of the World
item.description: Global competition in the Arctic is raising hopes of a revival in the town of Churchill. We went to meet the people, and the bears, there.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Known in recent years mostly for its polar bears, there are now efforts to revive infrastructure in Churchill, Manitoba.

item.title: Venezuela Oil Tanker Seized by U.S. Was Part of Effort to Finance Cuba
item.description: Firms with ties to Cuba are getting a larger share of Venezuelan oil exports, as the island’s security agents boost President Nicolás Maduro’s defenses.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Nicholas Nehamas and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: An oil tanker called the Skipper in the southern Caribbean Sea. It was seized by the United States.

item.title: To Get to Oslo, Machado Skirted Military Checkpoints and Survived Rough Seas
item.description: An American firm with experience in special operations spirited María Corina Machado, the recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, out of the country in a secretive land, sea and air operation.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Simon Romero
item.media:description: María Corina Machado spent the last year hiding from President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela’s regime.

item.title: U.S. Lifts Sanctions Against Justice Alexandre de Moraes of Brazil
item.description: A senior Trump administration official said that maintaining sanctions against Justice Alexandre de Moraes was no longer in the interest of the United States.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Alexandre de Moraes reading the charges against former President Jair Bolsonaro during the opening session of the trial in Brazil in September.

item.title: For Rubio the Cuba Hawk, the Road to Havana Runs Through Venezuela
item.description: President Trump’s secretary of state and national security adviser has long sought to cripple or topple Cuba’s government, which has close security and economic ties to Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s parents immigrated to Florida from Havana three years before Cuba’s communist revolution prevailed in 1959.

item.title: Canadians Rush to Buy Stockpiles of Boycotted U.S. Liquor
item.description: Four Canadian provinces are selling off the American liquor they pulled from shelves in protest over President Trump’s tariffs. Some bourbon drinkers are thrilled.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: American alcohol products were removed from store shelves in much of Canada when U.S. tariffs against the country went into effect in March.

item.title: In a Hamlet Built on Forbidden Love, a Cyclone Buried It All
item.description: Three generations of a family built their homes and lives in Sri Lanka’s highland tea country. The biggest storm in decades wiped out their hamlet in a landslide.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Pamodi Waravita and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Villagers carrying bodies for burial at a cemetery in Kandy in Sri Lanka.

item.title: Cyclone Aftermath in Sri Lanka
item.description: Mujib Mashal, our South Asia bureau chief, takes us to Kandy in Sri Lanka, which suffered the worst of the devastation from last month’s cyclone.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Christina Thornell, Christina Shaman, Laura Salaberry and Atul Loke

item.title: ‘Did We Do That?’ Gen Z Protesters Help Tip Balance Against Bulgaria’s Leaders
item.description: Young Bulgarians turned out in protests that helped unseat their government. Whether that will translate into higher turnout in upcoming elections is up to them.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Boryana Dzhambazova
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Sofia, Bulgaria, rallying against the government.

item.title: Germany Accuses Russia of Sabotage, Cyberattacks and Disinformation
item.description: The German foreign ministry’s announcement, which Russia denied, was the latest suggestion of growing Russian aggression in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: People lining up to vote in federal elections in eastern Germany last February. A spokesman for the German foreign affairs ministry said Friday that Russia spread misinformation about major candidates in the general election this year.

item.title: Iran Arrests Nobel Laureate Narges Mohammadi Amid Broader Crackdown
item.description: The human rights activist was released on furlough from prison last year, but was detained again on Friday, along with several other human rights activists.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Iranian Nobel Peace Prize winner Narges Mohammadi was arrested on Friday in the city of Mashhad.

item.title: A Trickle of Aid Reaches a Captured, War-Ravaged City in Sudan
item.description: A local group negotiated permission from the paramilitary force controlling El Fasher, offering a rare glimpse into conditions after a massacre.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A photograph released by Malam Darfur Peace and Development showing residents receiving sacks of millet the group delivered to El Fasher, in Sudan, on Dec. 2.

item.title: Joanna Trollope, Popular British Author, Dies at 82
item.description: Her books, many of which were best sellers, often described empty marriages, love affairs (with tasteful sex) and heroic clergymen.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Joanna Trollope after she was made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2019.

item.title: Russia Sues Holder of Frozen Assets Europe Wants for Ukraine Loan
item.description: The lawsuit was a warning to European officials who are racing to agree to a plan to use Russian government assets in Europe to lend money to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: The headquarters of the Euroclear depository in Brussels. Russia’s Central Bank said it had filed a lawsuit in Moscow against the depository.

item.title: Dozens Killed as a Hospital Is Bombed in Myanmar’s Brutal Civil War
item.description: Jets from the Myanmar military dropped two bombs on the facility in Mrauk-U, in what rebels and witnesses called a deliberate attack on civilians.
item.dc:creator: Verena Hölzl
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Mourners at a cemetery in Mrauk-U, Myanmar, on Thursday, grieving over the bodies of victims of a hospital bombing.

item.title: How Ukraine Has Responded to Trump’s Peace Plan and Russia’s Demands for Territory
item.description: A Ukrainian peace plan, sent this week to Washington, pushes back against President Trump’s proposal that Ukraine give up more land for peace, although Russia is unlikely to accept it.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said the Ukrainian peace proposal now being discussed consisted of three documents, one of which lays out plans for rebuilding the country.

item.title: Austria Bans Head Scarves in Schools for Girls Under 14
item.description: Austria’s centrist government passed the new law, which takes effect next year, after years of pressure from the far right.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Claudia Plakolm, Austria’s integration minister, said a head scarf law would help children’s rights. Critics said it infringed on religious freedom.

item.title: The Crime Involved Trash Bags. But It Wasn’t a Mob Caper.
item.description: Prosecutors say a city official on Jeju Island in South Korea stole more than $400,000 by pocketing the sale of government-issued trash bags that cost as little as 7 cents each.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: In South Korea, general waste must be put in official bags issued by the city. They are unique to each district and can be purchased from local stores.

item.title: How Power Cuts Are Affecting Ukrainians
item.description: Russia has been targeting energy infrastructure in Ukraine, leaving multiple cities without electricity. Kim Barker, who’s been covering the war, gives us a glimpse into the daily life of Ukrainians living with power cuts.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Oleksandra Mykolyshyn, Stanislav Kozliuk, Rebecca Suner and Leila Medina

item.title: Trump Says Leaders of Thailand and Cambodia Agree to Cease-Fire
item.description: Thailand’s prime minister said he had talked with the U.S. president, urging him to pressure Cambodia to resolve a deadly border clash, after a previous truce broke down.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Thailand’s prime minister, Anutin Charnvirakul, urged President Trump to step into the dispute with Cambodia once again, after an earlier truce broke down.

item.title: King Charles Shares ‘Good News’ About His Cancer Treatment in Video Message
item.description: The British monarch said that his treatment would be reduced in the new year, in a recorded message emphasizing the value of cancer screening.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III appearing in a prerecorded video released on Friday as part of a cancer awareness program.

item.title: China Is Getting Much of What It Wants From the U.S., Including Chips
item.description: For China, President Trump’s moves to loosen chip controls, soften U.S. rhetoric and stay silent on tensions with Japan amount to a rare string of strategic gains.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:description: President Trump and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, after their meeting in Busan, South Korea, in October. Mr. Trump’s latest moves extended the conciliatory posture he struck at this summit.

item.title: Reddit Sues Australian Government to Block Social Media Ban
item.description: The company said the new law, which makes it illegal for children under 16 to have social media accounts, infringes on children’s rights.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: School children waiting for a bus in Sydney, last month. The ban took effect on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Issues New Sanctions Targeting Maduro’s Family and the Oil Sector
item.description: The United States is escalating its pressure campaign on Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro, after seizing an oil tanker off the coast.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Tyler Pager, Farnaz Fassihi and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro during a rally in Caracas on Wednesday.

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s Seizure of an Oil Tanker Near Venezuela
item.description: The tanker was headed eastward and had recently carried Iranian oil. The seizure is an escalation in President Trump’s military pressure campaign against Venezuela’s leader, Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Nicholas Nehamas
item.media:description: A satellite image showing the Skipper, an oil tanker, near Port Jose, Venezuela, in November.

item.title: African Treasures Return Home
item.description: The Benin Bronzes, taken from what is now Nigeria, have become a symbol in the effort to return looted artifacts to their home countries.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: What Does the Oil Tanker Seizure Mean for Venezuela’s Economy?
item.description: Seizures of more tankers could put a stranglehold on Venezuela’s economy, which is exceptionally dependent on oil to keep the government running and pay for basic necessities.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil tanker docked at Cardon Refinery in Venezuela, in 2021.

item.title: Hamas Committed War Crimes in 2023 Attack on Israel, Amnesty International Says
item.description: The rights group said it had documented atrocities committed by Palestinian armed groups, including murder, imprisonment, torture and sexual violence.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers carrying a body in the Israeli village of Kfar Azza, which was attacked by armed militants on Oct. 7, 2023.

item.title: U.S. Helped to Weaken Report at U.N. Environment Talks, Participants Say
item.description: American officials joined Russia, Saudi Arabia and Iran in objecting to language on fossils fuels, biodiversity and plastics in a report that was three years in the making.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:description: The opening session of the 7th United Nations Environment Assembly in Nairobi, Kenya, on Monday.

item.title: Video Shows Skydiver Dangling From Plane’s Tail After Parachute Gets Stuck
item.description: A parachutist in Queensland, Australia, survived by cutting the chute free at 15,000 feet when a reserve parachute accidentally deployed, according to a government report.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: After Australia, Which Countries Could Be Next to Ban Social Media for Children
item.description: Governments are studying the decision to prohibit youths from using platforms like Facebook and TikTok as worries grow about the potential harm they cause.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Ida Marie Odgaard/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Elementary school children in Denmark, which could become the first country in the European Union to impose an age limit on access to social media.

item.title: Pakistan’s Ex-Spy Chief Sentenced to Prison After Court-Martial
item.description: Lt. Gen. Faiz Hameed, an ally of the former prime minister, Imran Khan, once led Pakistan’s powerful Inter-Services Intelligence agency.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood

item.title: Russia Warns Poland Over Arrest of a Researcher Wanted by Ukraine
item.description: Poland detained a Russian archaeologist who works on an ancient site in Crimea, which Russia seized in 2014. Ukraine calls the work illegal.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: The detention center where the Russian archaeologist Alexander Butyagin is held after being detained by Polish authorities, in Warsaw.

item.title: Killer Whales Find an ‘Unlikely Friend’ in Dolphins
item.description: Off the coast of British Columbia, dolphins lead killer whales to salmon and earn their share of lunch, a new study reveals.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: She Studied Mosquitoes to Prevent Malaria. Then She Lost Her Job at U.S.A.I.D.
item.description: Jenny Carlson Donnelly traveled to malaria-affected countries to test mosquitoes and save lives. Then she lost her job at U.S.A.I.D.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times

item.title: Bulgaria’s Prime Minister Resigns in the Face of Mass Protests
item.description: Prime Minister Rosen Zhelyazkov, the sixth prime minister in five years, bowed out amid public anger over corruption and democratic dysfunction.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Boryana Dzhambazova
item.media:description: Protesters filled the streets outside Parliament on Wednesday during an anti-government rally in Bulgaria’s capital, Sofia.

item.title: Zelensky Says Revised U.S. Plan Still Calls for Ukraine to Leave Donbas
item.description: The Ukrainian leader rejected the demand, making clear that territorial issues remain unresolved as Ukraine and Europe sent a counterproposal to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a Russian missile attack in Ternopil, western Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Here’s What to Know About Japan’s Mega Quake Advisory
item.description: Japan’s government says that the chances of a magnitude 8 earthquake have increased. Scientists can’t predict when one will strike, but it represents a meaningful jump over typical odds.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A vehicle teetered on a collapsed road in Tohoku Town off the coast of northern Japan.

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize Winner Machado Says U.S. Helped Her Leave Venezuela
item.description: María Corina Machado reappeared on the global stage as the Trump administration ramped up its pressure campaign against President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:description: María Corina Machado at a news conference in Oslo, Norway, on Thursday after spending more than a year in hiding.
